element.name: Aideen's Grave by snoopyandmickey, Traditional Cache (2/1.5)

long-description.p: Situated in the grounds of Howth Castle lies the remains of what would of been a huge megalithic monument, the now slipped quartzite capstone weights an estimated 75 tons which would place it second in size to Brownes Hill dolmen in County Carlow. The portal tomb is aligned South East and the two portal stones,each one an estimated 2 1/2 metres high, and door stone still remain. You can see in the picture middle left where the capstone has slipped backwards from the portal stones.

Folklore: Known locally as Aideen's grave this tomb is said to be the burial place of Aideen the wife of Oscar the son of Oisin. Oscar the bravest of all the Fianna slew three kings in his first battle, he died at the battle of Gabhra and it is said that Aideen died in grief at her loss, so Oisin buried her at Howth and set a cairn over her, a burial usually reserved for great warriors or kings.

Directions: From Dublin take the R105 North, as you come into Howth look for signs for Deer Park Hotel and Golf course on the right, drive into the grounds past Howth Castle and up to the Car park. Walk to the right of the Hotel and look for the path between the hotel and the pitch and putt course. Follow your GPSr from here.

It is highly recommended to take the spoiler picture as the tree coverage is very dense. Please refer to the hints for full details. There is public access through the golf course to this important monument.

center.font: Visit The Geocaching Ireland discussion forum HERE

element.encoded-hints: When looking at the spoiler picture the cache is 4 meters to the right under a tree stump.

ul.li:
2010-06-05T19:00:00Z : Found it by EIMHK
Found this while caching around Howth today - Great cache - very public place - signed the log as quickly as we could TFTC

2010-05-30T19:00:00Z : Found it by didi2206
This was great .. what a super place. Hadn't been along the rhododendron paths since 1974!!!! wow TFTC

2010-05-09T19:00:00Z : Found it by Toffee Man
Last find on a lovely sunny day caching with Blue Jay 59. TFTC Toffee Man #341

2010-05-09T19:00:00Z : Found it by Blue Jay 59
Really enjoyed the short walk through the woods to this one. We lucked out by coming at this time of year, I have never seen such big & beautiful rhododendron's. Many thanks for the cache & for bringing us here. Blue Jay 59 #341

2010-05-04T19:00:00Z : Found it by Crannyn
One of my favourite places for a walk.Love the flowers! Junior crannyn was disappointed as there was no TB. TFTC

2008-11-09T20:00:00Z : Found it by Kersti.com
Headed out this way with Anton and Gavin. I'd never seen the castle before so that was pretty cool :)
Once we got to the hotel I popped inside and some directions as to the easiest access to the grave.
Grave itself is a little run down, but still looks pretty cool.
The spoiler photo is spot on and after initially looking a tad too far away we very soon had the cache in hand.
Contents were mainly golf balls and tees so we dropped in some other goodies, including a nice coin.

wpt.name: GC13GJ0
wpt.desc: Aideen's Grave by snoopyandmickey, Traditional Cache (2/1.5)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Aideen's Grave
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
Situated in the grounds of Howth Castle lies the remains of what would of been a huge megalithic monument, the now slipped quartzite capstone weights an estimated 75 tons which would place it second in size to Brownes Hill dolmen in County Carlow. The portal tomb is aligned South East and the two portal stones,each one an estimated 2 1/2 metres high, and door stone still remain. You can see in the picture middle left where the capstone has slipped backwards from the portal stones.

Oscar the bravest of all the Fianna slew three kings in his first battle, he died at the battle of Gabhra and it is said that Aideen died in grief at her loss, so Oisin buried her at Howth and set a cairn over her, a burial usually reserved for great warriors or kings.


Directions: From Dublin take the R105 North, as you come into Howth look for signs for Deer Park Hotel and Golf course on the right, drive into the grounds past Howth Castle and up to the Car park. Walk to the right of the Hotel and look for the path between the hotel and the pitch and putt course. Follow your GPSr from here.


It is highly recommended to take the spoiler picture as the tree coverage is very dense. Please refer to the hints for full details. There is public access through the golf course to this important monument.



Snoopy and Mickey


"Enjoy the cache!"
